Wes

The submodule update for this repo has been raised here: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8741. 

Once this gets merged you can get the image from the artifacts available here. https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build

or once the CI is completed, you can use those artifacts here:  `https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=<buildId>&view=artifacts&type=publishedArtifacts`

Wes

I will run a test to see how much dataplane downtime improvement this PR brings in 201911 branch.

@vivekreddynv @dgsudharsan The new behavior is that the script will fail immediately if any command return error. However in reality, this is not convenient. Let's assume there is an image bug, some command fail or this script itself has bug, we still need to collect as much as possible data. Could you improve and let the following commands continue running?

> @vivekreddynv @dgsudharsan The new behavior is that the script will fail immediately if any command return error. However in reality, this is not convenient. Let's assume there is an image bug, some command fail or this script itself has bug, we still need to collect as much as possible data. Could you improve and let the following commands continue running?

Hi @qiluo-msft, 

The script will run in it's entirety (will create the archive with all the dumps) even though if any of the intermediate steps are failed. And in the end, it will exit with an rc=1 . 

But i understand the issue seen here https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1844.  When a timeout happens, the script returns with a non-zero exit code and bypasses the "Command timedout error log".  i believe that is fixed in the PR. 

Is exiting with non-zero code not okay in the command timedout case?
@yxieca to check

@arlakshm Can you please review and sign off?

@stephenxs -                                                                                                                                                                                                   Hi Stephan,                                                                                                                                                                                                          I have query regarding "The buffer configuration is stored in APPL_DB. The warm reboot will fail if the switch is upgrading from an image before this change to one after. So db migrator needs to handle APPL_DB as well."                                                                       I have not seen complete warm reboot design. Can you help me to understand, While warm/cold reboot db_migratory.py will trigger config_db update for qos right, which internally trigger swss to update APP_DB with new QOS field values right or during warmreboot swss will not process config_db updates?

> @stephenxs - Hi Stephan, I have query regarding "The buffer configuration is stored in APPL_DB. The warm reboot will fail if the switch is upgrading from an image before this change to one after. So db migrator needs to handle APPL_DB as well." I have not seen complete warm reboot design. Can you help me to understand, While warm/cold reboot db_migratory.py will trigger config_db update for qos right, which internally trigger swss to update APP_DB with new QOS field values right or during warmreboot swss will not process config_db updates?

The buffer tables are consumed from APPL_DB instead of CONFIG_DB. 
In a normal starting flow,
- the buffer manager generates table entries and pushes them into APPL_DB. 
- the orchagent consumes the entries in APPL_DB and pushes entries into ASIC_DB.

This is for both dynamic and traditional buffer models.
In a warm reboot flow,
- the `APPL_DB` is saved before warm reboot and restored after it, which means the entries consumed by the orchagent are restored instead of pushed by the manager daemons.
- the buffer manager generates table entries as well, but that's too late for warm reboot to meet its converging time.
- given the data format has been updated before and after warm reboot, we need to update the entries in APPL_DB as well

We have a similar flow which the entries in APPL_DB is prepared for warm reboot. [prepare_dynamic_buffer_for_warm_reboot](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/scripts/db_migrator.py#L269). It works for both buffer model.
Hope this helps.

As per the discussion in yang-subgroup-meeting (8/26) with @lguohan , we have decided to merge sonic-utilities PR (Azure/sonic-utilities#1626) 1st followed by sub-module update in sonic-buildimage. Then this sonic-swss PR (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/1754) should be merged.

Merge can happen in this order:
sonic-utilities PR for DB-migration logic : https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1626
sonic-buildimage PR for new config-DB changes : https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/7752
sonic-swss PR : https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/1754

> #### What I did
> 
> Provide a generic capability to show/main.py for platform extensions
> #### How I did it
> 
> invoke a new method called install_extensions() that is easily extensible for any vendor platform. Import the file if available or else move on.
> #### How to verify it
> 
> Enable vendor specific commands via the extensions. For instance, the below code extends the capability to support 'show platform idprom'. Logic can be extended per vendor needs.
> 
> @click.command()
> @click.option('--raw/--no-raw', default=False, help='Hexdump raw IDPROMs')
> @click.option('--all/--no-all', default=False, help='Dump all known IDPROMs')
> @click.option('--list/--no-list', default=False, help='List known IDPROMs')
> @click.argument('name', nargs=-1)
> def idprom(name, raw, all, list):
> """ Show platform IDPROM information """
> args = [ PLATFORM_PY, 'idprom' ]
> 
> ```
> if all:
>     if len(name) > 0:
>         click.echo('?Option --all ignored when given a list of IDPROM names\n')
>     elif list:
>         click.echo('?Option --all ignored when combined with --list\n')
>     else:
>         args.append('--all')
> if list:
>     if len(name) > 0:
>         click.echo('?Option --list ignored when given a list of IDPROM names\n')
>     else:
>         args.append('--list')
> ```
> 
> #### Previous command output (if the output of a command-line utility has changed)
> 
> does not exist.
> #### New command output (if the output of a command-line utility has changed)
> 
> root@sonic:/home/cisco# show platform idprom
> 
> board: [i2c:IO-MUX-0:0x50]/eeprom: /sys/bus/i2c/devices/17-0050/eeprom
> CHASSIS_SERIAL: FOC2330NCA3
> CLEI: UNASSIGNED
> CONTROLLER_TYPE: 1555
> DEVICE_VALS: 2414074587345059840
> ECI_NUMBER: ECI123
> GROUP_TYPE: 69

root@sonic:/home/admin# show platform inventory 
    Name                Product ID      Version         Serial Number   Description

Chassis
    CHASSIS             8101-32H-O      0.10            FHH2446P00A     Cisco 8100 32x100G QSFP28 1RU Fixed System w/o HBM, Open SW

Route Processors
    RP0                 8101-32H-O      0.10            FHH2444000T     Cisco 8100 32x100G QSFP28 1RU Fixed System w/o HBM, Open SW

Looks ok, need to revert the "show platform inventory" to cisco plugin file.

> Looks ok, need to revert the "show platform inventory" to cisco plugin file.

I am not clear on this. There was a discussion earlier to move 'show platform' related extensions to 'platform.py. Given 'inventory' is an extension to 'show platform' and is going to be platform (or vendor) agnostic moving forward in a distributed chassis environment, and hence, so just like: 

- show platform temperature
- show platform firmware
- show platform fan etc. 

I believe it makes sense to keep 'show platform inventory' in platform.py.

> > Looks ok, need to revert the "show platform inventory" to cisco plugin file.
> 
> I am not clear on this. There was a discussion earlier to move 'show platform' related extensions to 'platform.py. Given 'inventory' is an extension to 'show platform' and is going to be platform (or vendor) agnostic moving forward in a distributed chassis environment, and hence, so just like:
> 
> * show platform temperature
> * show platform firmware
> * show platform fan etc.
> 
> I believe it makes sense to keep 'show platform inventory' in platform.py.

@VenkatCisco, the general approach while adding a new functionality is to add/update the platform base classes defined in sonic-platform-common. This could be implemented by various platform (or vendor ) -- in their respective sonic_platform module ( eg: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/tree/master/platform/broadcom/sonic-platform-modules-dell/s6100/sonic_platform). Further we can have common scripts (eg: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/scripts/tempershow), to implement API's to get data from DB which could be populated by a platform daemon.

So the idea I was suggesting was to keep the "inventory" command under cisco plugin until we develop the infra surrounding abstracting/storing/retrieving the inventory data.
